results.title: ‘History Is Everything’: Making a Film About Black Maternal Mortality
results.abstract: The directors Paula Eiselt and Tonya Lewis Lee discuss their journey in making the documentary “Aftershock,” which shines a light on a national health crisis.

multimedia.caption: Shawnee Benton Gibson and Bruce McIntyre, at right, are central figures in the documentary “Aftershock,” about the abmysal death rates of Black mothers in the United States.
Shawnee Benton Gibson and Bruce McIntyre, at right, are central figures in the documentary “Aftershock,” about the abmysal death rates of Black mothers in the United States.

results.title: Meryl Streep’s One Weird Trick
results.abstract: The dramatic removal of eyeglasses is a cinematic cliché. On Streep, it’s a revelation.

results.title: The Unraveling of an Award-Winning Documentary
results.abstract: The director of “Sabaya,” about Yazidi women who had been sexually enslaved by ISIS, says that he wasn’t present for a key scene and that he substituted footage.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Sabaya,” directed by Hogir Hirori, about Yazidi women freed from a detention camp for families of ISIS fighters.
A scene from “Sabaya,” directed by Hogir Hirori, about Yazidi women freed from a detention camp for families of ISIS fighters.

results.title: Daisy Edgar-Jones Would Like the Ingénue Phase of Her Career to End Now
results.abstract: The star of “Where the Crawdads Sing” and “Normal People” has quickly become a Hollywood “It” Girl. But what she craves is longevity.

multimedia.caption: Experiencing her first success during lockdown was strange, Daisy Edgar-Jones said: When someone stared at her, she didn’t know if “they hadn’t seen another human being or if they had seen me in a show.”
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

results.abstract: The streaming service hopes its latest release can be the start of a blockbuster franchise that attracts much-needed subscribers.

results.title: Janeane Garofalo Never Sold Out. What a Relief.
results.abstract: That concept might be the reason her trailblazing stand-up career has been overshadowed; it may also be the reason she’s still so sharp, our critic argues.

multimedia.caption: Janeane Garofalo after a show in Brooklyn. In the ’90s she played a crucial role in turning stand-up comedy away from the polished, tight sets ready-made for a sitcom or TV appearance.
multimedia.copyright: Luisa Opalesky for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Where the Crawdads Sing’ Review: A Wild Heroine, a Soothing Tale
results.abstract: Daisy Edgar-Jones stars as an orphaned girl in the marshes of North Carolina in this tame adaptation of Delia Owens’s popular novel.

multimedia.caption: Daisy Edgar-Jones’s Kya is an irresistible if not quite coherent assemblage of literary tropes. Abused and abandoned, she is like the orphan princess in a fairy-tale.
multimedia.copyright: Michele K Short/Columbia Pictures/Sony Pictures Classics

results.title: L.Q. Jones, Who Played Heavies With a Light Touch, Dies at 94
results.abstract: His face was familiar, mostly in westerns, during a career that spanned five decades. He also directed the cult film “A Boy and His Dog.”

results.title: ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Enters the Pantheon of Conservative Fan Fiction
results.abstract: The American right has embraced Tom Cruise’s latest blockbuster, hailing the movie as a patriotic gesture produced in defiance of “woke” liberal elites and the Chinese Communist Party.
results.byline: By Blake Hounshell and Marc Tracy

results.title: Monty Norman, Who Wrote 007’s Memorable Theme, Dies at 94
results.abstract: He composed the instantly recognizable melody for the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” It has accompanied the agent on his adventures ever since.

multimedia.caption: The opening credit sequence of the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” Monty Norman’s “James Bond Theme” captured the public imagination.
The opening credit sequence of the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” Monty Norman’s “James Bond Theme” captured the public imagination.

results.title: ‘Marx Can Wait’ Review: A Director Digs Into His Brother’s Death
results.abstract: In a moving new documentary, the Italian filmmaker Marco Bellocchio gathers his fascinating, aging family members to make sense of their brother’s suicide.

multimedia.caption: Three of the Bellocchio brothers, from left: Marco, the filmmaker; Alberto; and Camillo, who killed himself at 29. In “Marx Can Wait,” the family’s surviving members delve into Camillo’s death.
Three of the Bellocchio brothers, from left: Marco, the filmmaker; Alberto; and Camillo, who killed himself at 29. In “Marx Can Wait,” the family’s surviving members delve into Camillo’s death.

results.title: ‘From Where They Stood’ Review: Auschwitz, as Seen by Prisoners
results.abstract: Christophe Cognet’s documentary pores over photographs, some of them clandestine, taken by prisoners, inside the Nazi concentration camp.

multimedia.caption: In one clutch of images, prisoners displaying wounds on their legs are revealed to be subjects of Nazi medical experiments.
In one clutch of images, prisoners displaying wounds on their legs are revealed to be subjects of Nazi medical experiments.

results.title: How the Colorful Costumes of ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’ Were Made
results.abstract: “The Phantom of the Opera,” “Big Trouble in Little China” and an archaeology museum all played a part, the designer Mayes Rubeo explains.
